Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: This is literally a whole word! Adding it to my personal dictionary.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: So, yesterday I started recording the audiobook of I’m Tired of Racism. So exciting!Instructions from the studio were to avoid wearing clothes that rustle and jewellery that jingle. Given that I’m usually in trousers or shorts and tee-shirts and wear silver bobs most of the time, it was easy to meet those requirements.The studio happens to be five minutes from my home at the end of an industrial estate. Despite that, it’s surprisingly quiet. Though it’s pretty unassuming from the outside, the mixing equipment is pretty impressive.I had a flask with a warm honey and lemon drink with me - that worked surprisingly well any time I started feeling a little hoarse. They also supplied water. That initial session was about 4 hours, and I’m doing another 2-hour session today.Once I finish my bit, the sound engineer will go back and edit out any mistakes (he described it as a clean recording, but there were still a few times where I stumbled over words and had to repeat stuff), and then the audio will be mastered. The guy who does the mastering will be out of town for a while, so I may not get the final version till late October, early November. There’s still lots to do in the meantime - audiobook cover design, for example. I’ll keep you posted.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: I've been shaken by some recent events, both personal and global, and I've had low capacity to create my own posts. That's how it goes sometimes, and it may last for a while longer.However, I have continued to share and amplify the voices of others, especially those better informed than I am. I saw something on Instagram recently that resonated (and lost it immediately, the feed being what it is). The gist of it was that as welcome as a "pause" is, you don't just pause a genocide; you have to stop it completely. I agree.Free Palestine. Permanent ceasefire now!What I said before still stands:I will not celebrate anyone's death.There is no excuse for genocide.There is no excuse for killing innocent civilians. There is no excuse for apartheid. Oppression is wrong. Occupation is wrong. And nothing good ever came from colonialism or imperialism.Finally, a reminder of what I believe and do my best to live: I am against bigotry, racism, discrimination and inequity. I'm for creating equality for deliberately disadvantaged folx and for everyone. I'm committed to continuing to learn and grow and to always doing better. Instant report and block for Islamophobia, antisemitism and hate speech directed at people who face isms.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: When someone shares their gender identity or sexuality with me, it's not my job nor is it my place to debate, deny, or diminish. They know themselves best.What I can, should and will do is acknowledge, accept and affirm their identity. (Changed to "identity" from "choice" - thanks Amanda Vail, MBA, FACHE, LCSW-S)They know themselves best.End of story.P.S. I'm still learning and I still mess up sometimes. I am always grateful to know better so I can do better.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Despite what the social media platforms would have you believe, high follower counts don't help you pay the bills. People who support your work with actual money in the form of contracts, projects, speaking engagements, subscriptions, purchases and donations DO help you pay the bills.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: "Does your empathy come with conditions?" I saw this on Instagram this morning, and it felt like a question we should all ask ourselves.Dehumanising people is not the way to go.Genocide is never ok.That is all.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: On Saturday, I finally had the Barbados launch of I'm Tired of Racism, released just over a year ago. My gratitude to Kathie Daniel of Southpaw Grafix Inc, who helped pull the launch together, to Professor Emerita Hazel Simmons-McDonald, who shared her view on the book in an excellent presentation, Stephen R. Smith of Pro Photo Studios Barbados, who took these wonderful photographs, my mother Kathleen, my husband Stephen, and my sister-friend Susan, who helped pull everything together before, during and after the launch. And my thanks, of course, to everyone who attended and made it a special event. Image 1 descriptionPhoto of a large rectangular cake iced in black and white, with the image of the cover of I'm Tired of Racism on top. It was as delicious as it looks. Baked by Fosters Bakery in Barbados.Image 2 descriptionLeft, a copy of Exploring Shadeism. Right a copy of I'm Tired of Racism. Both books are upright on picture stands. The cover of Exploring Shadeism features a woman's face divided in half, with one half black and the other white. The cover of I'm Tired of Racism has a black face with a single tear being shed.Image 3 descriptionPhoto of Ms Kathie Daniel, who served as emcee for the launch of I'm Tired of Racism. Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: I've been trying to gather my words for days but they remain stubbornly ungathered. So here's where I am: I've felt ill-informed and have been trying to fill my knowledge gaps without resorting to biased media outlets. So I've been listening to and learning from my Muslim and Jewish friends, and will continue to do so.Here are the things I know and hold to:There is no excuse for genocide.There is no excuse for killing innocent civilians. There is no excuse for apartheid. Oppression is wrong. Occupation is wrong. And nothing good ever came from colonialism or imperialism. As a Black woman, watching people spew vitriol on other Global Majority people awakens all kinds of trauma, both generational and from my own experience. The inhumanity of killing innocents is also traumatic.I will not celebrate anyone's death. And I will not countenance Islamophobia or antisemitism. (Immediate block and report if anyone does that on my post.)That is all for now. P.S. I've been following Rahimeh Ramezany 🧕🏻  and Emily O. Weltman, M. Ed. (among many others) as part of questioning all the things and getting better informed. Their posts have a wealth of information, so they're a good place to start if you've been in a similar space.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: At Mission Equality, we’ve been busy planning our next event, Equalism in Action. It’s an experiential learning event for senior leaders and leadership teams of organisations committed to providing safe and equal work experiences for their people. It will share what we’ve learned about creating equality in organisations, which is a LOT!We’re aiming for mid-May in New York City, but we don’t yet have a venue. A few people are already helping us find one (thank you!), but I’m also asking you, LinkedIn network, for your help. Ideally, we’d like a donated space for one day that can hold around 100-120 people. (A low-cost space would also work.) The space should have projection facilities and should allow for us to break into smaller groups within the room. Comping us a space is a great way to 1) work towards equality 2) support Global Majority founders. In exchange, you’ll get a mention whenever we mention the event, and we’re happy to offer free event tickets to a few people from the sponsoring organisation or organisations. We’re happy to talk about other forms of value exchange too.Can anyone help?Thank you! Please feel free to share this post or tag someone who might be interested in sponsoring us.[Image Description: The logo for our event in NYC in May this year - Equalism In Action: Building The Future Of Work Without Capitalism. The logo consists of the event name and tagline in white text around a rainbow-coloured skyline illustration of NYC, which includes the Statue of Liberty on the left hand side celebrating (the goal of equality, obviously) with both arms outstretched.]

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Apparently some people were offended. I lost a few subscribers over my post titled "No, You Can't Both Sides Bigotry".Interesting, right?I wrote this letter a while back after some whataboutery by a person in my network. Then I took a while to let it sit, and see whether I still felt the same. Most people know me as quite a "reasonable" sort of person, but sometimes I see red, and this letter is about one of the times I did. You know I always keep it real in the newsletter - this one was no exception. See what you think - I'll drop the link below.(And I'd urge anyone who feels troubled by the letter to sit with themselves and think about why.)

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: I've been planning the Barbados launch of I'm Tired of Racism. Yes, it's taken this long for me to get the books shipped here at a sensible price. (Sensible-ish, anyway - they'll still cost almost double what US buyers pay.)My budget for this is small so I'm saying no to the performance of these events and cutting my coat to suit my cloth. That means...- No single use banner - photos can be taken by the book signing table.- No projector hire - I'll email out the promo video a couple of days before.- No videographer - I have a good friend who's a professional photographer who will handle it.- No large menu of refreshments - a celebratory cake and some juice will work.- If decorations are needed, I'll use pot plants from my garden.- If there's stuff I already have that will work, I won't buy new.- Limiting the guest list.- Calling on my village to help me as I've helped them. And they have responded!And you know what? It's going to be great!

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Today, I added up sales of my latest self-published book, which are closing in on 1200 copies. (That doesn't include audiobooks, as I don't have those numbers yet.) But I thought that was a small amount till I checked the stats, which show that the average self-published book sells 250 copies. I personally know quite a few writers who have beaten those averages, so looks like we're doing ok.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: “Isn’t racism over?”This was an actual question I got from a white person I met In 2023. 2023!!!And it made me realise how much work there still is to do.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: "The recent issues are directed to white people who don't know much about anti-racism." This was a comment from someone who unsubscribed from my newsletter. I didn’t really buy it, but just in case, I looked back over what I’ve published since the start of the year:- an article on misogynoir and anti-Blackness, which the last time I checked is still happening- revisiting allyship- how I came to my personal stance on anti-racism (new topic)- what equality looks like for people who share my identity- allyship missteps (still happening every day)- BHM- a perspective on ancestry (new topic)- advice for white parents of Black kids (new topic)- what anti-racism looks like in 2024 (excerpts from podcasts I appeared in)- hypervigilance (still needed)- racism related to speech (new topic)- experiences when you and your kids have different heritages (new topic)- plus 7 interviews with founders and activists making change and 5 podcast episodesI’d say my recent issues - and all issues - are directed at people who want to keep being supported in their anti-racism journey AND those who want to see their experiences of racism reflected. This comment suggests that that person feels they’ve learned “enough”. My question is: can you ever?

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Ok, this officially made my day![Image description: Substack note from monks and mannequins above the cover image for an article titled "Anti-Blackness in a Restaurant."The note reads: "I highly recommend Sharon Hurley Hall’s posts for your regular consideration. They are not simple discursive events but an embodied witness of change in practice - it's like they say, the notes are not the music. Her insights have to be metabolized over time. I am grateful I found her."]

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: GETTING TO KNOW ME (August 2023 update)Hey LinkedIn folx, I was chatting with a new connection recently and realised it had been a while since I’d done a reintroduction. So here’s where I’m at: FOR AND AGAINSTI am against bigotry, discrimination and inequity. I'm for creating equality for deliberately disadvantaged folx. I'm committed to continuing to learn and grow and to always doing better.WHAT I TALK ABOUTHere on LinkedIn, I talk mostly about equality, anti-racism, self-publishing and book marketing, with occasional posts about startup life and wellbeing. If you want to see my content, you’ll need to follow, ring the bell on my profile, and hope for the best. I’ve been critical of how this platform treats Black and Global Majority creators, and I sincerely believe that’s resulted in a drop in visibility. That won’t stop me from writing, but if you want to keep up to date, it’s a good idea to subscribe to my newsletters. I have two - one on anti-racism which has paid subscriptions - and a free one where I republish (and sometimes expand on) some of the stuff I post here. Some people see my content there before they see it here, which is kind of wild. MY ROLESI am a Co-Founder of Mission Equality CIC. Our name is our goal. We believe in education as a driver of change on the path to equality. We’re working hard on a series of Mx of Equality programmes to shift the way we think so we can do better. The first two will cover business and anti-racism, and we’ll also set the scene with a foundation course for all our programmes. We’re yay close to releasing the first parts.I'm the author of "I'm Tired of Racism: True Stories of Existing While Black" - the book where global majority people feel seen and would-be allies get an insight into global Black experiences. Released in October 2022, the book hit several bestseller milestones, including:- #1 new release in Essays (Kindle)- Top 10 Discrimination and Racism Studies (Amazon Canada)- Top 20 Discrimination and Racism Studies (Amazon US)- Top 50 Discrimination and Racism Studies (Amazon UK)- 80+ five star ratings on Amazon, Goodreads and Kobo (if you've read it and you have the bandwidth to write a short review, I'd be grateful, as that boosts Amazon visibility).The book is available digitally in multiple stores, though only Amazon has the print versions. I’m just about to start work on the audiobook, which I hope to release later this year. As I mentioned, I am the founder and curator in chief of Sharon's Anti-Racism Newsletter, where I offer my global perspectives on racism (via articles and a mini podcast) AND a platform for other activists and Black founders (via interviews). It has more than 5000 subscribers, of whom 300 or so are kind enough to offer their financial support. (I’d really love to find another 200 people who feel the same.)Thanks for being here. Linky goodness in the comments - and I'd love to know what made you follow me.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Just when you think you’ve seen it all, you find there’s another way for people to attempt to exploit would-be writers. One of my soon to be ex-connections asked me to get involved in a scheme - I can only call it a scheme - which sounded like vanity press meets MLM. He said I’d be a featured author and all I had to do was persuade 10 more people to write a chapter in a co-authored book. I’d get my spot for free; they’d have to pay $1300 apiece. And we were guaranteed bestseller status.I’m internet old, and my spidey senses tingle at anything that seems too good to be true. And this did, big-time, on many fronts. In addition to being outraged that he’d think I’d invite anyone to this “nopertunity”, I’m concerned that some people might fall for this, but it's definitely a case of "buyer beware". As far as I can tell:- The person who offered the nopertunity will be getting $13,000 per book - the writers get nothing up front- There’s a promise of an unspecified revenue share (not sure for what) plus 30% of online sales royalties (for comparison, I get 70% of the royalties on my self-published print on demand books)- My friend Jenn, who’s a whiz at these things, has detected a whiff of the link farm in how his site is set up (which will result in Google penalties)- It looks like after the book is published, you’re encouraged to buy more tools and services to boost sales (so more revenue for his company and less for the writers)That’s without even digging into who owns the book and the material in it, and other pertinent questions. For example, what if his company stops promoting the book? Because 30% of nothing is nothing. In short, the people contributing chapters would be getting the very short end of a particularly crappy stick, in my opinion. As a writer, if you decide to go the self-publishing route, it’s best to have your own platform. And while it makes sense to pay for some services, like professional editing and cover design, there’s a lot you can do yourself. No, you probably won’t become an instant bestseller (though you never know), but you will get all your royalties, and you’ll be able to sleep at night, too. cc Jennifer Mattern#publishing #selfpublishing

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Hello folx,I’m going to keep this short and sweet. It’s International Women’s Day 2024 and the SARN (Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter) store is live!Why today? Because #IWD could do with being a bit more intersectional and inclusive, don’t you think? So that’s why I chose it.There are just a few products to start with - don’t worry, more are coming - in two collections, the logo collection and the quotes collection. And there’s also a gift card, in case you want to give the gift of SARN merch to anyone.For those who like tech details, products are made by Printful, and the store runs on Wix, created with not a little sweat and tears, more than a little swearing and the absolutely invaluable help of Lisa Hurley, who of course knew the ins and outs of both platforms because of her The Great Exhale  store - thanks again, Sis!For those who subscribe to the newsletter, if you’ve ever thought, “that should be on a SARN t-shirt”, feel free to remind me of your favourite quotes and I’ll consider them for products in the future.Finally, this is a work in progress. As a recovering perfectionist, I aim to live by the mantra “done is better than perfect”, though I still have high standards for myself, lol. There’s definitely stuff I want to tweak., and I plan to get to it in the next couple of weeks.Head on over and check it out. Link in comments (and if the URL looks kind of familiar, it's because I grabbed several versions of the newsletter URL when I set it up ;) )And let's not forget: #CeasefireNowNobody's free till everybody's free - Fannie Lou Hamer

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Some random thoughts for today.Thought #1It’s almost time for me to publish my annual roundup of what works for Black creators on LinkedIn, but I’m not going to. Because nothing works. (For me, anyway.)It’s the luck of the draw at this point, and my profile is very unlucky, as are those of many of the people talking about social justice.I will keep working with this broken system for now, but I have no more advice on this topic.Thought #2If everyone who follows me on LinkedIn subscribed to my free Substack (the sharonhurleyhall one), there would be enough momentum so I could do what other creators have done - publish mostly there and only occasionally here - and reach ALL the people who are interested in my work and my content, not just those that LinkedIn deigns to let past their gatekeeping algorithm.Thought #3And if everyone who follows me on LinkedIn donated $1 a month on my Ko-Fi page, I’d be able to spend all my time doing this work without worrying about how to pay my bills. I mentioned this in conversation with a friend recently and she immediately donated $12. (And yes, not everyone can and that's totally fine. I can't support all the folx I'd like to, either, but I will be able to one day.)Makes you think, doesn’t it?Hope you all have a great weekend!And you know where the linky goodness will be.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: This weekend I've been listening to the files for my audiobook. While it's clear that I'm not a professional voice artist, I think there's a power in me telling my own stories.Looking forward to releasing this in November - date to be confirmed.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Ok folx, the I'm Tired of Racism audiobook is finally happening! I've been uploading the files today. Mysteriously, despite a couple of us having checked the audio multiple times, one file is missing. I don't think it'll be an issue, as I know it's been recorded and edited - I just need to get it from the sound engineer. Stay tuned for the release date which is planned for February 2024. For those who enjoy tech details, I'm using Findaway Voices (a partner of Draft2Digital which I used for wider ebook distribution). That means the audiobook will be available not just on Audible, but on a wide variety of audio platforms and libraries, including Spotify, if I can get it to work. Setting up my account there was simple, as was starting a publishing project. There are useful prompts for everything you need to do. So far, so good. [Image description: screenshot of a Findaway Voices audio upload screen showing three audio files and onscreen tips. The files shown are opening credits, dedication and acknowledgements).

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Read and absorb. My approach to an allyship misstep or fail is the same as Lola Bakare shares here.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: I don't know about you, but issues about anti-racism and equality are never far from my mind. Once you are aware of oppression, it's hard to avoid that being a lens through which you make sense of the world.So it's not a surprise that while I was doing some light reading, I noticed something odd about the characters in a book. It was moving along nicely when the writer threw in a mention that one of the characters was Black. But it was odd, in that it seemed a gratuitous mention at that point in the story. So I went to check who the writer was. She appeared to be white. Which is fine but the way she was writing about the Black characters suggested  she had no experience of the Black community. Which is not fine.How did I pick up on that? Because in just a few pages she managed to trot out some stereotypes about anger, violence and hypersxuality in relation to Black people. Apart from that the characters were largely one-dimensional.No amount of Black with a capital B (sprinkled liberally throughout the book) could camouflage the fact that the author was too far removed from what she was writing about and therefore couldn't make the characters well-rounded. What's also worrying is that her portrayals are adding to the mass of stereotypes that are already out there.This isn't the representation we need or deserve.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: What paradigm are you operating from on the path to equality?How can we rethink what hasn't worked and come up with new solutions?We have these conversations all the time at Mission Equality CIC. Hit me up if you'd like to learn more about our approach.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: "I'm Tired of Racism" has been selected for quite a few book clubs - now I'm making it easier with a starter book club kit. The kit includes:- an exclusive "behind the book" essay- links to 2 sample chapters- 10 questions/prompts to kick off discussion (though of course you can add your own)It's currently available on a PWYW basis - https://lnkd.in/eFUzT3Ff

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: "They are keeping me isolated from certain people on here so we don’t all *sit together in the cafeteria* and stir up good trouble." - • Theresa M. R.When I saw that, it resonated. There are people I've followed and rung bells for whose content I never see. And there are people who tell me "I thought you were on a LinkedIn sabbatical". If you haven't seen my stuff, check out my profile every so often. I'm still here posting and sharing most days and getting double-digit views with more than 20K followers. IYKYK 👀 [emoji: side-eye] And follow my work in other spaces like my newsletter, Mission Equality's newsletter and my website. Talk soon!

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Powerful!

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: If I've been quiet since I returned from my trip, it's because I've been working - HARD - on two things:1. The anti-racism curriculum Mission Equality CIC is creating for YWCA Southeast Wisconsin - it is coming along beautifully!2. Content for our upcoming Mx of Equality programme - we've been tweaking to make it even more impactful. If you're in our first cohort, you'll be hearing from us very soon. I feel a real sense of purpose with this work, and am enjoying the alignment of the personal and "professional" at Mission Equality!

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Lucy Webster captured my feelings exactly in her latest newsletter. I feel the same in relation to racism:"Being a lived-experience activist is hard. There is no line between my job and my life. I love what I do, I would not do anything else for anything else, but it is relentlessly difficult, relentlessly personal, relentlessly never enough. You give so much of yourself - in the case of the book, all of myself - and then you open Twitter to see the latest instance of egregious ableism and wonder whether anything you do can ever make enough of a difference, if you’re ever doing more than shouting into the void."

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Sending appreciation to all those who've checked on me because I've been a bit quieter than usual. Nothing is wrong; I've just been keeping busy.One of the things I've been busy with is shifting focus on what was Mission Equality CIC's anti-racism MxE to something that's broader and more focused on the end-goal (while still recognising the steps we need to take to reach that goal). I'll be talking about that more in the coming days and weeks.I've also been making arrangements to start recording the I'm Tired of Racism audiobook. I'll keep you posted on that.And I've been scheduling my newsletter for this month. Here's what's coming up:- My monthly behind the scenes letter (supporters; already published)- "Isn't racism over?" (all)- mini podcast x 3 (supporters)- Of restaurants and racism (all)- Discouraged but determined (all)- Never have I ever (anti-racism edition) (supporters)- Decolonising the mind recap (all)- A letter to my Black child (supporters/all)- September reading list (all)How's September started for you, friends?

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Today I read: "We cannot read ourselves into true change." It resonated. Yes, we need to learn, but gathering information is not enough to change the status quo. We also have to take action, however we can.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: "Here’s what many Global Majority people, myself included, have observed in the offices we’ve worked in: there are people who consistently do the minimum but get the maximum reward. Those people don’t tend to look like me. And there are people who go above and beyond, and may not get any reward at all, other than some quiet firing. Those people tend to look like me." Who can relate?

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Posting this here while I sort out some tech issues on the back end - please share with other SARN subscribers. You’ll remember I posted recently about the platforming and promotion of N*zis on Substack. The founders finally responded, and it seems they’re ok with that. I didn’t feel I could stay on the platform, and so I’ve moved the newsletter to beehiiv. While the underlying platform is different, the domain remains the same - see the link in my profile.Ideally, that shouldn’t change anything. You should be able to login with the email you used for Substack and have access to the same content (I haven't finished designing the site there, but except for the podcast, it's all there.)I'm now manually removing Substack payment plans in Stripe (don't ask) so nobody gets charged twice. beehiiv ones have already been created, so nothing should else should change. Once that's done, I'll have another look at platform features, make some tweaks, and should be back to normal in early January. (FYI, Mission Equality CIC and The Introvert Sisters will also be removing their publications from Substack)

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: We've all worked in places where we've had to push through whatever is happening for us personally - and it can be super hard. Over time many people become stressed and unwell because of toxic work cultures.It doesn't have to be that way. We've been working differently at Mission Equality CIC from the start - and it's a game changer! And we'd like to share what we've learned so others can do it too. In this video, I share a personal experience of just how different it is.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: "We don't think of Black people often as having privilege but the truth is we all enjoy some privilege in some circumstances." "We can enjoy privilege and still be hurt by the pain of racism."These quotes are from my recent conversation with Dr. Jonathan Ashong-Lamptey. In the excerpt in today's newsletter, I discuss where I do and do not have privilege, and what that looks like.Linky goodness below.

Post Text: "It is our unspoken caste system that led people to assume my biological, white father had adopted my older brother and me.It is caste that leads people to assume I am my biological son’s caretaker.It is caste that elevates whiteness while simultaneously devaluing blackness and brownness." - powerful words from Naomi Raquel Enright

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: LET'S TALK!We’ve got a lot of stuff to talk about at Mission Equality CIC - and I’d love to talk to YOU about it.Stuff like:- Why we focus on equality as the end-goal rather than anti-racism and anti-discrimination (though those are important equity steps)- How business and leadership need to change to create a more equal workplaces that work better for everyone- Why we want to create an educational resource that’s free for kids around the globe- The reason we keep creating Black Papers- The ideas that need to change to create a more equal world - and why we’re sharing some thought starters and paradigm shifters on social media.Got questions? Invite me to your podcast or show, or hit me up if you’d like to have a conversation.#MissionEquality #MissionEqualityCIC

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: For those wondering how long it takes to put together my newsletter, here's an interim report. I publish approximately 8 articles/interviews and 2 podcast episodes a month. I batch write in advance when I can so that when it's time to schedule I have only the editing to do. Each original piece can take up to an hour to write - they're usually around 700-800 words long. Some write themselves, some take longer. When it's time to edit and schedule, that's usually another hour apiece.Interviews are submitted via a form and usually only need light editing. Editing and doing the graphics can take around 45 minutes to an hour for each piece. (And yes, mistakes and typos still slip through occasionally - I'm human.)When I can, I write podcast content before recording it. The episodes are short, but they probably take 30-45 minutes each when you include recording and re-recording, creating transcripts and graphics and doing the actual post. That adds up to around 15 hours a month just on the content creation piece. That does not include backend admin, keeping track of stats, tweaking templates, responding to comments or dealing with tech issues. And it definitely doesn't include social media or other marketing.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: The trouble with reactions is that they are no substitute for a nuanced comment. Now that the "curious" reaction is gone on LinkedIn, I have to use the "insightful" for everything from "that was a great share that made me think and added to my store of knowledge" to "that really gave me an insight into how you think and I'm wondering".And in some cases, I'm content to read and not react if I don't have the bandwidth to comment.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: LinkedIn network, Mission Equality CIC is looking for your assistance to help YWCA Southeast Wisconsin find a corporate sponsor for its mentoring breakfast for young women, coming up as part of its flagship Circle of Women event on September 21, 2023. The theme of this year’s event is “Power of a Pivot.”The overall sponsorship need is $45,000. However, any sponsorship level will provide seats for community members who could benefit from this opportunity but don’t have the funds.The session will allow 30 young women and girls from Southeast Wisconsin to meet women leaders who have excelled in both their professions and their lives for a private mentoring session. Please share this widely and help make this opportunity available for young women in Southeast Wisconsin. And if you’re able to help, please reach out to CEO Tracy L. Williams - event email is pivot@ywcasew.org. Thanks for your help!

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: Ever noticed that when people start talking about work, stories of toxicity and trauma often surface? What if there were a better way to lead so we had less trauma and more equality? That's what Mission Equality's MxE in Business and Leadership aims to model and create.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: If you're going to design for equality in business, you need somewhere to test out your ideas. For us, that's our company, Mission Equality CIC. From the start, we set out to design and model what equality in business looks like, and we've made some tweaks along the way.We know a LOT about the practicalities of doing this - and we share those in our Business and Leadership MxE and with progressive leaders who want work to work better for everyone. Get in touch if you'd like to learn more - we are ALWAYS happy to talk about equality.And feel free to share this post or tag anyone who you think would like to talk to us.[Image description: White text on black background reads "Our company is our lab." Underneath is an an icon of a microscope and test tube. The next line reads: "We like it that way." At the the bottom is the Mission Equality rainbow shield logo above the hashtag MissionEquality.]#MissionEqualityCIC #EqualityInBusiness #EqualityInLeadership

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: At Mission Equality, we're busy planning our next event, Equalism in Action. But we need your help. Our chosen venue in NYC has fallen through, so we're pushing the event back to the fall, and are still looking for a donated or low-cost space to hold around 100 people for a day (or two half-days). The space should ideally have projection facilities and should allow for us to break into smaller groups within the room. Thanks to all who have helped so far.The event is envisioned as an experiential learning event to provide inspiration, practical steps and our own frameworks for creating equality in organisations, which is something we know a LOT about!We're happy to offer free event tickets to a few people from the sponsoring organisation or organisations, and to consider other forms of value exchange.Can anyone help?If you know someone who'd be willing to donate a space, please share this post or tag someone we should talk to. Thank you!

Post Text: "Thank you, Sharon! This is exactly what I had in mind." Writing takes practice. I write the way I do because I've honed my craft for more than three decades.But, as many of you know, I'm no longer a full-time freelance writer. I write less often (though probably still more than many people). So it was great to get this feedback today from my remaining client, and to know that the writing muscle still works.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: If you're a freelance writer and you're not following Jennifer Mattern, you're missing out. I've known her for a while now (15+ years) and she gives no-nonsense advice based on actual lived professional experience. As an experienced (though no longer active) freelancer, she's one of the people I go to when I need advice. She is super-smart, and I trust her opinion on freelancing, PR and tech especially.Check out All Freelance Writing Kiss My Biz and Freelance Writing Pros to start with.

Author: Sharon Hurley Hall
Post Text: What does equality mean to you? What about equity?At Mission Equality CIC, we believe that equality means everyone gets their needs met in the way that works best for them and allows them to thrive. That doesn’t mean what’s needed is the same for everyone. (Also, having needs isn’t pathologised - we ALL have needs.)And equity? That’s what we do to level the playing field till true equality exists. Equity steps are necessary now. When true equality exists, we won’t need them - and won’t that be something?!I personally love the vision of a time when people who are currently deliberately disadvantaged aren’t playing catch-up, don’t you? Getting there will take strong, committed leadership which operates from a different paradigm. It’s something we’re doing - and learning from - in our company. If you aspire to be that kind of leader, I’d love to talk to you about how we’re already working to realise that vision, and how we’d like to help others do it too. DM me if you’d like to hear more.
